subject: RE: [junit] JUNITas Ant-Task in Eclipse 2.1
msgSnippet: I am running ant in WSAD 5.0 (based on eclipse 2.0). I think the problem may be that junit.jar is not in the ant build path. Look at prefrences external tools
messageBody:
I am running ant in WSAD 5.0 (based on eclipse 2.0).

I think the problem may be that junit.jar is not in the ant build path.
Look at prefrences external tools and add junit.jar to the ant class path
and see if that helps.

Let me know if I can be of more help.

Randy

To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] JUNITas Ant-Task in Eclipse 2.1


Servus,

does anyone has some experiences in using JUNIT in conjunction with ant
and eclipse 2.1?

I tried to run my tests in many different ways and I have seen many
different error-messages, but never got the expected resultsâ˜¹


That's the ant-target:

<target name="test" depends="compile">

<junit printsummary="yes" haltonfailure="no" fork="yes">
<classpath>
<fileset dir="${libdir.src}">
<include name="**/*.jar"/>
</fileset>
<pathelement path="${classes.target}"/>
</classpath>
<formatter type="xml" usefile="yes"/>
<test name="biz.beaglesoft.rb.gmw.network.TestAllTests"
todir="./web" outfile="result">
</test>
</junit>

</target>



In the ${libdir.src} there is a junit.jar that holds the class
junit/framework/TestListener. This junit.jar is also added to the
[window.preferences.externaltools.ant]-ClasspathDialog. But
nethertheless I got the following exception:

java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: junit/framework/TestListener
at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass0(Native Method)
at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java:493)
at
java.security.SecureClassLoader.defineClass(SecureClassLoader.java:111)
at java.net.URLClassLoader.defineClass(URLClassLoader.java:248)
at java.net.URLClassLoader.access$100(URLClassLoader.java:56)

If I delete this junit.jar-entry from that Ant-dialog I get the
following error-message:
BUILD FAILED: E:\Develop\gmwproto4test\build\build.xml:157: Could not
create task of type: junit. Common solutions are to use taskdef to
declare your task, or, if this is an optional task, to put the
optional.jar in the lib directory of your ant installation (ANT_HOME).

I think it should be possible to get junit running under eclipse from
within ant, so please, could anybody give me a hint?

Have a nice and peacefully day

Wolfgang
